Description: Lip sherd of Laconian, probably black-figured, pottery kylix; interior: frieze of alternating red and black tongues; exterior: two black (fired reddish) bands at rim above triple pomegranate pattern with red on 'fruit'.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Boston 88.1076, Reading 26.2.82 and Oxford AN1896-1908-G.133.8. It was published by Lamb as coming from a Corinthian plate. Venit notes that the painted triple pomegranate pattern is used only by the Naukratis Painter.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 37, pl. XVIII, no. 47) (Listed as Corinthian)
Venit 1985 / Laconian Black Figure Pottery in Egypt (p. 395, no. 6)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 549, no. E7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GC.59) (phase 3)
